name: Lee Anne Guryn
title: Long term entertainment
review: I got this as an extra thing for a trip in the car with three girls ages 10, 8, and 5. They had IPads and books. We were in the car for three weeks, traveling the west of the US. This toy was a winner. Everyone played with it at least once a day and each child would use it for at least 15 minutes. It got stepped at least twice and did not break. This is going on my gifts for all kids list. I highly recommend it. Note: one child is autistic and this was very engaging and calming for her.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2020
name: BBP
title: Lots of fun!
review: The media could not be loaded. Magnetic ball bearing art tablets like this one from Magblock are really neat. They're much better than the erasable pressure-based magnetic drawing pads you might be more familiar with in some ways. The ball bearing matrix offers much better precision and kids can be more meticulous with each dot. Running the pen over the tablet quickly also works. We like open-ended toys that encourage creativity.The pen tip is magnetic and sucks the ball bearing into a hole. To "erase" just push the ball back down with fingers. A booklet of drawings is included if your child needs ideas.Things that could be improved upon: The tablet should have a handle for easier carrying by little hands. The pen should also have an optional tether. Also, I think the plastic could stand to be a bit thicker.If you're looking for more of these kinds of dot tablets, Apfity has ones that teach how to write letters and number: Apfity Magnetic Alphabet Letter Tracing Board, ABC Magnetic Tablet Drawing Board for Kids, Magnetic Letter and Number Tracing Board for Toddlers Preschoolers.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2020
name: Booknerd28
title: The pen is NOT attached
review: I ordered this because we have an alphabet one for my toddler, trying to help him learn to write. The baby and him are constantly fighting over it, so I got this one for her to play with. Both kids LOVE using these and love popping the metal balls back in just as much (you know the pop tabs on soda lids at the drive through....same concept).However....THE PEN IS NOT ATTACHED to this one like it is on his alphabet one. The baby was constantly walking off with the drawing pen and leaving it in random places all over the house.I'm going to have to figure out a way to hot glue it with a ribbon otherwise it's going to vanish.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2020
name: Terry in SA
title: Interesting and well made
review: This Magblock Magnetic Stylus Drawing Board is interesting and well made.So this is a plastic box with a grid of perforations on the front and contains hundreds of tiny, magnetic balls. It comes with a magnetic stylus that, when touched to a perforation, pulls a ball up into the hole. Keep touching perforations to "draw" with the magnetic balls. The balls are all silver so color is not possible but you can create some surprisingly complex drawings with this toy. To "erase", just run your finger along the balls and they fall back into the box.The perforations are small so it's not possible to pull a magnetic ball out through the holes. The plastic box is very strong so I have no worries about durability under normal play situations. There is a magnetic indent on the front that holds the stylus securely when not in use.This is a good toy for riding in the car or for solitary play. Since no color is possible, it likely will not engage kids for hours but I think it's well worth the $12 price tag.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2020
name: Posh Gypsy
title: Pretty boring
review: This wasn't as much of a hit that I thought it would be.It was intended for my 5-year-old nephew and my 4-year-old niece when they came to visit.I showed them the included booklet so they could copy how to make the different patterns, but they wouldn't even give the booklet a glance.They would flip it over so that all the dots appears in the "up" position, and then have fun poking the ball bearings out again.Or they would draw lines to hear the satisfying pop of the ball bearings.
